sen.j: 五瀬命（いつせのみこと）は、日本神話に登場する日本の皇族である。
sen.e: Itsuse no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
Itsuse no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
Itsuse no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 日本書紀では彦五瀬命（ひこいつせのみこと）とも表記される。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name is also written as Hikoitsuse no mikoto (彦五瀬命)
sen.cmt: 彦五瀬命（ひこいつせのみこと）→Hikoitsuse no mikoto (彦五瀬命)と漢字表記を加えました。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name is also written as Hikoitsuse no mikoto (彦五瀬命).
sen.cmt: 文の最後にピリオドを追加
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name is also written as Hikoitsuse no mikoto (彦五瀬命).
Description in the mythology
Description in the mythology
Description in the mythology

sen.j: ウガヤフキアエズと、海神の娘であるタマヨリビメの長男として生まれた。
sen.e: He was born as the first son between Ugaya Fukiaezu and the daughter of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea), Tamayoribime.
sen.cmt: 統一用語リストにはUgaya Fukiaezuとありましたが、ウガヤフキアエズ→Ugayaｆukiaezuとしました。
sen.e: He was born as the first son between Ugaya Fukiaezu and the daughter of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea), Tamayoribime.
He was born as the first son between Ugaya Fukiaezu and the daughter of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea), Tamayoribime.

sen.j: 弟に稲飯命・御毛沼命・若御毛沼命（磐余彦尊）がいる。
sen.e: His smaller brothers were Inani no mikoto, Mikenu no mikoto, Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).
sen.cmt: 統一用語リストには以下のようにMikotoと大文字になっていましたが、「命」のつく名称はすべてmikotoとしました。稲飯命：Inani no Mikoto、御毛沼命：Mikenu no Mikoto、若御毛沼命：Wakamikenu no Mikoto、磐余彦尊：Iwarehiko no Mikoto
sen.e: His younger brothers were Inani no mikoto, Mikenu no mikoto, and Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).
sen.cmt: smaller brothers を younger brothersに変更。
sen.e: His younger brothers were Inani no mikoto, Mikenu no mikoto, and Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).

sen.j: 磐余彦尊が後に初代天皇である神武天皇となる。
sen.e: Later, Iwarehiko no mikoto became the first Emperor, Emperor Jinmu.
Later, Iwarehiko no mikoto became the first emperor, Emperor Jimmu.
sen.cmt: jinmuを jimmu に変更（n--> m）
sen.e: Later, Iwarehiko no mikoto became the first emperor, Emperor Jinmu.

sen.j: 弟たちとともに神武東征に従軍したが、浪速国の白肩津（あるいは孔舎衛坂）での長髄彦との交戦中に長髄彦の矢に射られた。
sen.e: He went to Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) with his smaller brothers, but during the battle against Nagasunehiko at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) (or Kusaezaka) in Namihaya no kuni (Namihaya Province), he was hit by the arrow that Nagasunehiko sent.
sen.cmt: 神武東征→Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) としました。
sen.e: He joined Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) with his younger brothers, but during the battle against Nagasunehiko at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) (or Kusaezaka) in Namihaya no kuni (Namihaya Province), he was hit by the arrow that Nagasunehiko had sent.
sen.cmt: went to をjoinedに変更、 smaller brothers をyounger brothers に変更。sent をhad sent に変更。
sen.e: He joined Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) with his younger brothers, but during the battle against Nagasunehiko at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) (or Kusaezaka) in Namihaya no kuni (Namihaya Province), he was hit by the arrow that Nagasunehiko had sent.

sen.j: 五瀬命の「我々は日の神の御子だから、日に向かって（東に向かって）戦うのは良くない。廻り込んで日を背にして（西に向かって）戦おう」
sen.e: Itsuse no mikoto advised his troops as '[n]ow that we are the sons of the sun, we should not directly proceed toward the sun (to the east), let's proceed fighting with our back to the sun (toward the west).'
sen.cmt: 日の神の御子→sons of the sunとしました。
sen.e: Itsuse no mikoto advised his troops as 'now that we are the sons of the sun, we should not fight facing the sun (the east), let's turn around and fight with our back to the sun (the west).'
Itsuse no mikoto advised his troops as 'now that we are the sons of the sun, we should not fight facing the sun (the east), let's turn around and fight with our back to the sun (the west).'

sen.j: という助言によって一行は南へ廻り込んだが、紀伊国の男之水門に着いた所で、射られたときの傷が悪化した。
sen.e: Following his advice, the troops took the indirect route, getting around toward the south, but when they reached Onominato in Kii Province, his wound got serious.
Following his advice, the troops marched toward the south to turn around, but when they reached Onominato in Kii Province, his wound got serious.
Following his advice, the troops marched toward the south to turn around, but when they reached Onominato in Kii Province, his wound got serious.

sen.j: 五瀬命は「賊に傷つけられて死ぬとは」と雄叫びしたので、その地を男之水門（雄水門）という。
sen.e: It is said that Itsuse no mikoto roared a virile cry, '[w]hat a pity that I should die from a wound by the rebel,' and therefore, this site came to be called Onominato (literally floodgate of virility).
sen.cmt: 雄叫び→定訳不明：roared a lamentable cryとしました。 「賊に傷つけられて死ぬとは」→定訳不明：'what a pity that I should die from a wound by the rebel' としました。 「雄叫びしたので、その地を男之水門（雄水門）という」とあったので、男之水門（雄水門）→Onominato (literally floodgate of virility)としました。
sen.e: It is said that Itsuse no mikoto roared a virile cry, 'what a pity that I should die from a wound by the rebel,' and therefore, this site came to be called Onominato (literally floodgate of virility).

It is said that Itsuse no mikoto roared a virile cry, 'what a pity that I should die from a wound by the rebel,' and therefore, this site came to be called Onominato (literally floodgate of virility).

sen.j: 古事記によれば紀国男之水門で、日本書紀によれば紀国竈山で亡くなり、竈山に陵が築かれた。
sen.e: After he died at Onominato in Kii Province according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), and at Kamayama in Kii Province according to the Nihonshoki, his mausoleum was constructed at Kamayama (Wakayama Prefecture).

After he died at Onominato in Kii Province according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), or at Kamayama in Kii Province according to the Nihonshoki, his mausoleum was constructed at Kamayama (Wakayama Prefecture).
sen.cmt: and at Kamayama を or at Kamayama に変更
sen.e: After he died at Onominato in Kii Province according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), or at Kamayama in Kii Province according to the Nihonshoki, his mausoleum was constructed at Kamayama (Wakayama Prefecture).
Comments
Comments
Comments

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では、「五瀬」は「厳稲」の意味とし、穀物や食料の神の意と解している。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), 'Itsuse' (五瀬) is understood as (厳稲) (literally, majesty of rice), and therefore, he was identified as the god of crops and foods.
sen.cmt: 「五瀬」→'Itsuse' (五瀬) と漢字表記を入れました。 「厳稲」→正式な読み方が不明です：(厳稲) (literally, majesty of rice)としました。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), 'Itsuse' (五瀬) was understood as (厳稲) (literally, majesty of rice), and therefore, he was identified as the god of crops and foods.
sen.cmt: is understood をwas understoodに変更
sen.e: According to "Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), 'Itsuse' (五瀬) was understood as (厳稲) (literally, majesty of rice), and therefore, he was identified as the god of crops and foods.

sen.j: 和歌山県和歌山市竈山に陵墓（彦五瀬命墓）がある。
sen.e: His Imperial mausoleum (Hikoitsuse no Mikoto's tomb) is located in Kamayama, Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture.
His Imperial mausoleum (Hikoitsuse no Mikoto's tomb) is located in Kamayama, Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture.
His Imperial mausoleum (Hikoitsuse no Mikoto's tomb) is located in Kamayama, Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: そのすぐ南に五瀬命を祀る竈山神社がある。
sen.e: Kamayama-jinja Shrine that enshrines Itsuse no Mikoto is found just to the south of the tomb.
Kamayama-jinja Shrine that enshrines Itsuse no Mikoto is found nearby to the south of the tomb.
Kamayama-jinja Shrine that enshrines Itsuse no Mikoto is found nearby to the south of the tomb.

sen.j: また、岡山県岡山市の安仁神社に稲飯命 ・御毛沼命.とともに祀られている。
sen.e: He is also enshrined at Ani-jinja Shrine in Okayama City, Okayama Prefecture, with his brothers Inani no Mikoto and Mikenu no Mikoto.
He is also enshrined at Ani-jinja Shrine in Okayama City, Okayama Prefecture, with his brothers Inani no Mikoto and Mikenu no Mikoto.
He is also enshrined at Ani-jinja Shrine in Okayama City, Okayama Prefecture, with his brothers Inani no Mikoto and Mikenu no Mikoto.
